item.author: Gobot
item.description:
That is a surprising finding -- I would have expected stressed men to prefer more self-similar faces.
But as long as we're telling evolutionary tales, here's another explanation: Humans select self-similar mates to the extent that they have confidence in their own genes, and higher stress levels predict less confidence. The basic idea is that you're always assessing how you have the best chance of passing on your genes: self-similar mates should share lots of your genes, but then your kids might end up facing the same stresses that you've faced. If these stresses are too intense, then your offspring might fare better by being less similar to you -- so you choose a less self-similar mate.

item.author: fred jolly
item.description:
Might I ask if it is common practice for medical journals to write articles that appear to set different research papers and their authors against each other? Mr Kean describes the situation like a baseball match with phrases such as 'second major hit' and 'fallen apart under scrutiny'. It doesn't set a particularly dignified or impartial tone for such an esteemed publication.
Might I also ask whether David Griffiths has been party to the protocols used by the WPI to isolate XMRV in ME? If not, then I would further ask how he is able to state "All the people involved are doing things exactly as they should be". Surely only the WPI can judge this.
Finally, might I request that Mr Kean/Science looks more closely at the sample selection of this latest UK research? Fukuda criteria only were used, whereas the WPI used Fukuda and Canadian, the latter being a much 'tighter' diagnostic protocol that focuses on neurological symptoms and 'weeds out' psychiatric illnesses.
To demonstrate the issue of ineffective sample selection, at a localised level, the 'Dorset cohort' used by SGUL is drawn from the Dorset CFS (sic) Centre which offers graded exercise and cognitive behavioural therapy to treat ME, a fact which dissuades people with 'a "real" disease' (as Mr Kean so quaintly puts it) from attending. It is more than likely, therefore, that blood samples from genuine ME patients in this location are still in the patients and not in the test tubes.
It was very encouraging to see Science take on the challenge of breaking the stigma attached to ME and publishing the original XMRV article in October 2009. I hope that the journal continues in this vein and resists the temptation to make a spectator sport out of the subsequent research trials and errors.

]"> Thu, 18 Feb 2010 23:33:35 +0000
Heidi Bauer
WPI's response - http://www.wpinstitute.org/news/news_current.html
February 18, 2010: WPI is aware of the recent UK study that was unable to detect the presence of XMRV in any CFS patient samples. Although researchers at the WPI were not involved in this project, our work in XMRV continues with researchers around the world. We look forward to the results of studies which replicate the methods used in the original research described in the journal Science in October, 2009. View more...
Information Regarding XMRV Studies
1. The authors of the Science paper established the existence of XMRV as an infectious human blood borne retrovirus for the first time in blood of patients diagnosed with Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS). Previous studies had established the presence of XMRV sequences and protein in human prostate tissue.
2. In the Science paper, the presence of XMRV in well-characterized patients with CFS was established using multiple technologies:
a) PCR on nucleic acids from un-stimulated and stimulated white blood cells; b) XMRV protein expression from stimulated white blood cells; c) Virus isolation on the LNCaP cell line; and d) A specific antibody response to XMRV.
3. The authors of the two UK studies did not attempt to replicate the WPI study. Replication requires that the same technologies be employed. The WPI sent reagents and information to several groups of researchers in an effort to support their replication studies. Neither UK study requested positive control blood, plasma or nucleic acids from the WPI.

jsid-1266535953-954 <jskit:attribute key="like" value="[{
profile: '35GRjgRvBvEXxOVOTkVzlQ',
name: ''
}
]"> Thu, 18 Feb 2010 23:32:33 +0000
Heidi Bauer
Continued...
4. The collection, preparation and storage of DNA were completely different between the Science and UK papers. The latter studies do not show data on blood harvesting or storage. Nor do the studies disclose the quantity of isolated cells. Insufficient number of cells analyzed may result in failure to detect a low copy virus like XMRV, regardless of the sensitivity of the assay. Neither UK study provides detail to allow interpretation of how many white blood cells were analyzed.
5. Patient population selection may differ between studies.
6. The UK authors were unable to detect XMRV, even though 4% of healthy individuals were found to be infected in the US. Japanese scientists detected XMRV in 1.7% in healthy blood donors in Japan. The two previously identified human retroviruses have distinct geographical distributions.
7. Perhaps the most important issue to focus on is the low level of XMRV in the blood. XMRV is present in such a small percentage of white blood cells that it is highly unlikely that either UK studys PCR method could detect it using the methods described. Careful reading of the Science paper shows that increasing the amount of the virus by growing the white blood cells is usually required rather than using white blood cells directly purified from the body. When using PCR alone, the Science authors found that four samples needed to be taken at different times from the same patient in order for XMRV to be detected by PCR in freshly isolated white blood cells. More importantly, detection methods other than PCR showed that patients whose blood lacks sufficient amount of XMRV detectable by PCR are actually infected. This was proven by the isolation of viral proteins and the finding of infectious XMRV isolated from the indicator cell line LNCaP. The authors of the Retrovirology paper admit that their neutralization assay did not detect bacterially expressed XMRV gag and that positive control sera was needed to validate their assay. The WPIs monoclonal antibodies specifically and sensitively completed the immune response demonstrating the assays sensitivity and specificity for XMRV envelope.
Simply stated the only validated reliable methods for detecting XMRV in CFS patients, to date, are the methods described in Science. Failure to use these methods and validated reagents has resulted in the failure to detect XMRV. A failure to detect XMRV is not the same as absence of this virus in patients with CFS.

item.author: miggs
item.description:
jonjski, you make fair points, but we must also take into account that current regulations make cogeneration more difficult and less profitable than it should be. We don't have a free electricity market. We have protected utilities that are largely insulated from competition and given no incentive to do things efficiently.
To be sure, I'm associated with the company chaired by Tom Casten, mentioned in the article. At Recycled Energy Development (recycled-energy.com), this is the stuff that staff members live and breathe, so perhaps I'm biased. But there really is remarkable potential here, if only market forces would be unleashed. Estimates from LBNL, McKinsey, and elsewhere suggest recycling waste energy could slash our greenhouse gas emissions by 20%, even as energy costs fell due to increased efficiency. How could we not pursue policies to make that a reality?

item.author: jonjski
item.description: I suppose you academics got paid to stuble across this revelation? Cogeneration have been engineered for will over 40 years. As with all processes, it isn't about whether the process can be done, it's whether it can be done economically; whether it is in the business interest of the heat generating facility; and whether they want to be bothered with operating a facility that is not a part of their core business. Heat recovery plants that produce electricity are expensive, require constant maintenance, and require personnel additions that may make the the difference between a profit or loss making venture. Must everything be legislated to occur? Market forces will drive the the formation of companies that will make use of the wasted energy. The best success in this area would be for a company with experience in operating and maintaining heat recovery generation plants to contract for the heat and build, operate, and maintain such facilities on a large scale basis, allowing them to capitalize on the economies of scale that such operation would provide.

item.author: John Hwalek
item.description:
"Similarly, heat from burning fossil fuel at a power plant can be recycled, doubling the efficiency of electricity production and thereby halving CO2 emissions."
This is a dubious claim considering second law efficiencies. Most conventional power plants are about 35% efficient in converting heat to electricity while the maximum second law efficiency is about 50%. If I read this correctly, you are claiming the efficiency can be increased to 70%. This would violate the second law. The problem is that most waste heat is at a low temperature which means it has a low potential to produce work.

item.description:
I completely agree with yerband in both issues: first it is annoying and disappointing that Science is deleting comments without any public explanation....
second, for some reason the most obvious experiment would have been the use of synthetic RNA instead mouse-derived liver RNA to create infectious recPrPres... this would have clarified many doubts about the nature and contamination concerns of this "synthetic prions". Just for the sake of the study and as a definitive proof! They did show that synthetic Poly-Adenine served as co-factors for replication only in vitro, but did not show whether they can promote the spontaneous generation of recPrPres or infectivity. These raises some questions:
- Were these samples ever injected? - Why did they start using liver-derived RNA in first place which is much more laborious to obtain instead of buying synthetic poly-adenine and show a more real "mammalian-free" system to generate synthetic prions? - Why did the recPrPres samples was mixed with highly concentrated BSA when injected in mice?

item.author: yervand karapetyan
item.description:
IS RECOMBINANT PRION PROTEIN BY ITSELF INFECTIOUS?
The authors claim (science.1183748) that recombinant prion protein from E. coli, converted into a protease resistant form (rPrP-res), caused scrapie disease in mice. However, the mixture also contained normal mouse liver RNA and synthetic lipid. Before inoculation this mixture was subjected to multiple manipulations (serial dilutions, sonication etc.) in a laboratory that previously contained RML scrapie infected brain and other mouse tissues. Control inoculum #2 (rPrP, RNA, lipid, buffer) was only incubated without subjecting it to serial dilution and sonication, supposedly to prevent rPrPres formation. They also had rPrP-res negative sonicated samples with the same components as inoculum #2 and did not use any of these as a negative inoculation control. Moreover, the rPrP-res seed was not directly injected, another essential control.
Recombinant prion protein alone without either RNA or lipid was previously converted into a protease resistant form by others (1) and was not infectious. In contrast, RNA isolated from infected brains was required for infection (2). This leads one to suspect that contamination with RNA coming from RML infected scrapie material in the lab was responsible for the observed infectivity reported. Indeed, the immunohistochemical staining pattern of pathological prion protein in the figures looks the same as in brains infected with standard RML scrapie (3).
References
1. R. Atarashi et al. Nature Methods, 4, 645 (2007) 2. S. Simoneau et al. Natureprecedings (2009): http://precedings.nature.com/documents/3344/version/1 3. Y.E. Karapetyan et al. PLoS ONE, 4, e5730 (2009)

item.author: brandon

"definitively linked the evidence to a flask of anthrax under Ivinss control"
This has always been claimed by the FBI and refuted by basically everyone that worked with Ivins. Custody of the famous "flask" was shared by dozens at USAMRIID, and it was also revealed that the strain of anthrax it contained was shared with other labs.
Ivins' coworkers also have raised great doubt about Ivins' ability to even create the type of weaponized anthax that was used in the attacks. He was an expert in liquid solutions of anthrax, and the equipment necessary to create fine anthrax powder was not found in his lab.
I just hope that you all dig a little deeper here before putting this issue to rest. Shame on sciencemag for leaving out the relevant and important viewpoints of Ivins' colleagues.

John
What is going on is that in general there is an existential problem for the Recent Out of Africa construction.
Really sophisticated human behavior begins with the explosion of culture among the Cro-Magnons -- who suddenly appear in Western Europe 45,000 years ago, already of Northern European physical type. Recent evidence shows that a gene for larger brain development originates in Europe (Lahn PNAS vol 103, p 18178) and spreads out from there (and egads, still hasn't reached all present-day human populations). Kennewick Man, mtDNA Haplogroup X, the Boskop Skulls, the Ainu, the lighter-skinned, European-featured Fulani in West Africa, and a host of other evidence largely suppressed from scientific consideration today, shows that there was indeed an expansion of peoples of Caucasian physical types around the world before, during, and after the last glacial maximum.
In other words, at a minimum, *fully* modern Homo sapiens sapiens evolved in Europe 40,000 years ago, and present-day humans have (mostly) been elevated to (degrees of) fully modern status by waves of European expansion and intermixing. The sudden appearance of these ultra-sophisticated Cro-Magnons from nowhere even looks suspiciously like they evolved in Scandinavia not Africa in the first place, and got pushed down by the advancing ice sheets which scraped away the evidence.
Well the entire political imperative of Recent Out of Africa is to re-write that history into something that contradicts "racist colonialism" instead of validating it.
And this is why the coordinated cabal of Leftist/globalist researchers dominating anthropology today has in general been desperate to find signs of culture in Africa to predate the Cro-Magnons. This has become even more pressing with recent research (von Petzinger and Nowell) demonstrating that not only did the Cro-Magnons have magnificent realistic sculpture and painting -- they had a set of abstracted, language-like symbolic glyphs.
So now you have the context for some crude decorative scratches on eggshells in Africa -- which in no way are detachable, reconfigurable symbolic units -- being grandly elevated to a revolution in "symbolic communication".

item.author: Mark
item.description: Hi Aaron. What you're missing is that the cost of electricity varies thoughout the day in direct relation to load. So, in the middle of the afternoon when businesses are open and air conditioners are running, utilities have to buy power at premium prices, typically from diesel-fueled peaker plants that only run during peak demand times. With grid-connected EVs, the utility can draw power from willing drivers and pay them the going peak rate. The driver then charges at night when demand is lower and prices are less. Voila - profit!

Just be sure to take anyone out of the power reserve pool if there is a likelihood of their needing the full battery backup (such as when a hurricance or a strong winter storm is coming).

item.author: Ron Cram
item.description:
Climategate has been a wonderful development because it has opened people's eyes to the very unscientific manner in which climate science has been produced. First, they claim a "consensus." When a skeptical paper is submitted for publication, they circle the wagons to kill the paper. Then they say, "If the skeptics were doing good science they would get their papers published." When the alarmists want to publish a paper, they seek out Pal Review instead of Peer Review. When McIntyre wants to audit an alarmist paper, they refuse to provide data, methods or code. This is not science. The whole process is dirty. It reminds people of the way Enron did business before they collapsed. See http://climateaudit.org/2010/02/24/rob-bradley-climategate-from-an-enron-perspective/
This is a news story about a group of scientists gathered bemoaning the fact their reputations have been hurt. Well, guess what, if you hadn't sat on the sidelines while fights were going on to get data, methods and code, people would have more respect for you. The journals, like Nature and Science, that refused to enforce their own policies regarding openness and data sharing have been hurt badly in the credibility department. It is an ugly thing to see advocacy raise its head in science.
Judith Curry of Georgia Tech is trying to lead the way to more trust between scientists in both camps. Her essay is much closer to the mark of what climate scientists ought to be saying. See http://curry.eas.gatech.edu/climate/towards_rebuilding_trust.html

This climate change thing has become so political it makes me sick. And it is the fault of both sides--the liberal as well as the conservative right.
Liberal scientists who want to believe in climate change are skewing data to dovetail with their beliefs and right wingers are doing the same. No wonder the data is so inconsistant. If you want to get a grant, just pick the side you want to win, apply to the powers that be for the grant money, and then make sure the numbers fit your and their preconceived ideas so they will give you more grant money in the future for more skewed studies.
No wonder scientists are being pictures as whores. They are acting like whores. And then scientists of both sides are saying the public is stupid? Nope, the scientists of both sides have become dishonest and biased.
I'm a middle of the roader--I dislike both the republicans and democrats equally. In this case I tend to lean slightly to the left, only because I don't need global warming to want us to become less dependent on foreign oil. There is plenty of financial evidence, which is more believable than todays slut science, to get away from oil.

item.author: Guest
item.description:
The first duty of scientists is of course to do reliable science but the second is to give advice to policymakers. (To policymakers, not to the public.) Scientists just hope that policymakers react and inform the public and implement laws.
We know since the 70ies that atmospheric CO2 is increasing. You all probably know the Keeling curve (which is solid data). The glass house effect was proposed to lead to Global Warming. If this is known since the 70ies, why did nothing change and we burn oil as usual? Maybe because Global Warming is either not yet approved or not well enough communicated. (Or just ignored)
Can you imagine how frustrating it can be to monitor the planets degeneration day by day and recognize that nothing really changes or nobody cares? (Not only concerning climate, there are many other things to worry about.) Even with all the advice given to politicians. I appreciate very much that the general public is waking up and that politicians (at least in some countries in Europe) start to implement laws that already help reducing CO2 emissions.
In general, people don't like changes, so they don't like to adapt their lifestyle or accept that the environment around them is changing. But the environment will also change without their approval. Climate change seems to be too slow to be recognized and also the grains of our global community grind slowly. Anyhow, I am confident that there is a generation growing that will soon replace people that still prevent changes. Such is life. It is dynamic and always (sometimes unexpectedly) changing. It is the task of policymakers to make decisions to maintain a sustainable economy in a dynamically changing environment. I doubt that politicians are able to do so without the help of scientists.

It is about very wealthy and powerful interests determined to crush all opposition no matter where it comes from. The best analogy (though not of this scale) is the example of the tobacco industry, deny, distract and delay were their watchwords which worked incredibly successfully for them for many years. The science was clear, but it made absolutely no difference to those very powerfulo actors. item.author: Mueller
item.description:
The deniers of climate change appear to have this discussion (and unfortunately many others) where they love to have it: so the Himalayan glaciers won't be gone by 2035 but by what, 2300? This is anybody's guess, because if it's an accelerating process it's too early to tell when it ends. However, this does not mean that the evidence for anthropogenic climate change has been demolished: only the time scale has changed, which means we'll all be dead by then. In many humans' minds this raises the question why act now while we have to pay for it. In addition, this way we can avoid necessary changes affecting those whose lobbyists have been busy funding congress people to derail any effective legislation.
We argue about how fast we are going downhill towards a cliff instead of starting to find and hit the brakes. Major reason for this imprudent behavior is that we have extreme difficulties to look ahead 5 years, much less 15 years, or 50, 100, 250 years. That's what makes 2035 vs. 2300 so important to those who oppose effective measures to curb greenhouse gas emissions: 2300 means this danger disappears from most humans' minds compared with day-to-day worries about food, shelter, employment, health insurance, etc. Thus, they can deny the existence of the slope and the cliff. For most scientists, however, 2035 or 2300 does not change the fundamental problem. It also does not change that we need to start hitting the breaks now, because hitting them 2300 will be far too late (that's like hitting them when already going over the edge of the cliff).
Our descendents won't be happy about our inaction, but by then we won't have to care anyway. So, let's throw in climate change with all those other problems about which we don't want to worry right now or for which we don't feel like paying out of stalling or decreasing real incomes. Next generations, however, will have to pay multi-fold to battle the accumulated omissions.

item.author: Jim Lemon
item.description: The Himalayan glacier story is important not because it demolishes the evidence for anthropogenic climate change. It doesn't. It is unfortunately consistent with the hypothesis that the statement was made because it looked like no one would challenge it. Who would go to the Himalaya to check out the story? In Australia we have just had a lecture from the government about how our beaches will disappear with rising sea levels. There is little doubt that this will be countered by someone with a basic knowledge of coastal sediment transport, providing the climate sceptics with yet more ammunition. The temptation to emphasize the importance of one's data by going beyond it has been the ruin of many scientists, and we would be wise to leave that sort of behavior to the politicians.

item.author: Gwen Keller
item.description:
The key to prevention of crime hotspots is community involvement in their own security. Communities that are more vigilant and secure their homes properly, that form neighborhood watch groups, that don't allow abandoned buildings and lots to go untended are less likely to draw criminals. Communities that interact proactively with the local police force create a safer environment and become less attractive to criminals.
For instance, the city of Dayton, Ohio has strong community involvement in crime prevention. The police chief of Dayton, Ohio, Richard Biehl has the philosophy that crime prevention is the responsibility of citizens and police working together. He began a popular weekly talk show, "Taking it to the streets" where police and citizens voice their concerns. Chief Biehl stated that " When I became Chief of Police in Dayton, one of my key goals was to enhance communication efforts with residents and engage the entire community in crime prevention and education efforts [and] this new monthly television show is just one way to do that.
Dayton also is a member of the Weed and Seed program, a U.S. Depertment of Justice sponsered program to weed out bad influences in cities and seed in good programs that help to keep crime at bay. Information on this program can be found at: http://www.daytonnorthwestweedandseed.org/.

item.author: JeffBaranchok2
item.description: PART TWO 2. If we had contracted a government agency in 1980 to build a cheap, compact, portable computer, the result would have been an unaffordable and barely workable kluge of "brilliant ideas". Instead, the market-oriented free enterprise system evolved the amazing and affordable and indispensable laptop powerhouses and internet technologies that we know and love today. I believe we should try this approach to make crossing the Earth-to-orbit barrier more economic. It may take 40 years to get there, but once we are there we'll be able to afford manned missions to anywhere in the solar system, and we'll have done it while making a profit and creating productive jobs. A simple economic analysis shows that fuel is a small fraction of launch costs and that the real money is in hardware and staffing. Therefore in order to get to orbit very cheaply, space flights need to be very frequent and the hardware must be highly reusable with minimal turnaround effort, thus minimizing the depreciation and overhead costs per flight. Im thinking, at minimum, weekly flights by a 95+% reusable vehicle. The flights must be dedicated to carry passengers or freight ONLY and not transport the living quarters from Earth to orbit each time. This means there must already be destination living quarters in orbit. From our Space Shuttle experience, we already know that a "revolutionary" approach to creating such a vessel is not likely to be successful. What application fits this hypothetical space vessel design to a T"? Scientific and exploratory missions? Hardly. Scientists and explorers will stay in space for weeks or months at a time, and/ or their missions will be infrequent. Such missions have no need for weekly launches. The obvious solution is space tourism - the classic week-long vacation trip to a "far-away exotic destination". Certainly at the present, planned services to launch people to a 60-mile altitude for a "glorified roller coaster ride" (no offense) is a couple of orders of magnitude away from putting people into orbit, but there DOES appear to be a market there for wealthy early adopters. Over time, these people will demand bigger and better thrills, and these businesses will want to make their services accessible to a larger number of less affluent clientele. Their space ships will gradually go farther and higher, more reliably, and more cheaply by the evolutionary experimental methodology used by all new industries. If it is at all possible to accomplish low-cost weekly flights into orbit akin to commercial trans-continental airline flights, THIS is the way the technology should be developed, NOT by government mega-projects. Once the tourism market has developed the economic reusable launcher, that should make it much cheaper to lift exploratory hardware and crews into orbit (if in fact wealthy private adventurers dont beat governments to the finish line first!!).

item.author: Dr. Biology
item.description:
Thanks for the mention. The AAAS Family Days event was great. We had a lot of fun meeting people and showing off the new Ask A Biologist website.
In case anyone is interested, the answer to the question from the young biologist about the largest single-cell organism is below. As is often the case, what seems to be a simple question can actually have more than one answer.
"What an interesting question. To start I have to ask what exactly does "large" mean? The heaviest, the longest, the most voluminous? Let's see if we can help out. Here are just some of the answers to this question.
The largest cell (Volume) on Earth would be an egg of an emu or ostrich, no other type of cell has the needs of storage that an egg does, and only a large animal can produce eggs the size of an emu egg.
The longest cell would be a nerve cell several feet long in a human (+ the speculation of elephant, giraffe and giant squid nerve cells being larger!).
Since you mentioned bubble algae The answer to this may well be Caulerpa, a green alga, that has essentially one body cavity in its 6 or more foot body, although with many nuclei. It has morphological definition of organs, so it is remarkable whether it fits the requirements of your definition or not.
Thanks for the great question."
Dr. Biology

item.author: Robert Houston
item.description:
LHC experiments should be subjected to thorough computer simulation before high energy collisions are instituted in reality. In this way potential harm to the machine and environment could be red-flagged in advance. When the assumptions are uncertain, alternate assumptions could be used. For example, what would happen if there's an extra dimension and if Hawking radiation fails to disintegrate black holes that might form?
According to the article, "Physicists say that such black hole[s] would harmlessly decay into ordinary particles." But a more accurate wording would be, "Not all physicists say..." For example, Prof. H. Stocker, in a study supported by the ALICE collaboration at the LHC, has written that "there are equally strong indications that the black holes do NOT evaporate completely, but rather leave a meta-stable black hole remnant (BHR)..." (his emphasis). (Stocker, J. Phys. G 32:S429-37, 2006, at S433; see: iop.org/EJ/abstract/0954-3899/32/12/S52 .)
Dr. Stocker points out that such BHRs "could be used as a source of energy... The total 2050 yearly world energy consumption...could be produced..." Wouldn't such a large energy release be dangerous? Another German physicist has calculated that "it would appear like a major nuclear explosion in the immediate vicinity of the collider." (R. Plaga at arxiv.org/abs/0808.1415v3 - p. 9).

item.author: rain storms
item.description:
Dear Mr. Dodds,
No, it could not be, on any of those counts.
Note that you have confused relative and absolute humidity in your first paragraph. You have also confused yourself regarding the spatial and temporal scales involved with global warming versus a rain storm. Also note that the greenhouse effect is not as simple a relation as the fractional change in humidity equals the fractional change in temperature; such a statement would violate conservation of energy.
As the absolute humidity in the atmosphere increases, the greenhouse effect does in fact get stronger. In an instance of a rain storm, though, there are competing effects on the temperature. When there is a rain storm, the sky will be overcast, greatly reducing insolation at the surface. The surface continues to cool via infrared emission, and much of that radiation will be absorbed by the overlying, humid atmosphere. The local temperature will not, however, instantly warm in this situation. That extra energy does go to warm the column, but competing effects from, for instance, the cooling by evaporating rain drops are much larger than the modest warming from the surface. Such evaporative cooling along with radiative cooling within the column will decrease the temperature, which increases the relative humidity and decreases the amount of vapor that can be held by the air, which would decrease the potential absorption of infrared radiation. Rain reaching the surface also influence the surface temperature, changing the infrared emission, which is not in energy balance because of being cut off from the solar radiation as an energy source. Also, there are dynamical effects, such as the "cold pool" formed near the surface, which expands outward from the rain shaft. This cold pool spreads, increases surface turbulent fluxes around the rain shaft, and transports energy, mass, and momentum out of the rain shaft vicinity. These effects are all much larger than the local radiative transfer. When you go to much larger scales and much longer times, radiative balance becomes the dominant effect though, and the greenhouse effect is relevant for average temperatures.
Interestingly, though, you should look at satellite images of "OLR" (outgoing longwave radiation), as you can clearly see that colder emission temperatures are associated with deep convection and big rain storms. The reason is that the effective height of emission is the cloud top, which is a a much cooler temperature than the underlying surface.

item.author: Rebecca
item.description: Placebo is a good thing, when used against colds, headaches and the like. The problem is that some forms of sickness aren't treatable with placebos. Providing medicines as if they were really effective against a certain illness, for example cancer, when in fact they do nothing beyond what the persons mind puts the body into doing (which unfortunately rarely does miracles against deadly illnesses) is really dangerous. Who would want a mere placebo as medicine against a possibly deadly illness?

Who cares if it's placebo effect. That fact is it provides a positive outcome with out the risk of the negative effects associated with many pharmaceuticals. Better idea, end anti-depressants. When we look at all studies (not the cherry picked ones the pharmaceuticals cite) one anti-depressant is as good as another. Slightly, better than a placebo. The apparent advantage of placebo can be explained by the fact that in double blind tests, subjects and researchers have a pretty good idea the drugs that produce side effects are the drug being tested (not the placebo). Researchers and medical teams treat patients with side effects differently and patients that believe that they are receiving the "real" drug tend to have better results than patients who are unsure. How many other drugs could we end on the placebo effect argument?

It is surprising and shocking to see how arbitrarily the British Committee comprising of the honorable members of parliament dismissed a whole system of medicine as a mere placebo effect. Since the days the German physician Samuel Hahnemann invented homoeopathy in 1796, millions of people follow this system. Personally I use the system of medicine since last 20 years and successfully treated number of chronic and acute diseases. I appeal to all the homoepaths wold over to fight the case tooth and nail. item.author: Leon Arundell
item.description: This article presents conclusions that are not adequately supported by the evidence. Fowler confused correlation with causation. He has validly observed that people who lack sleep network with other people who lack sleep. From this, he has concluded that networking with people who lack sleep causes people to lack sleep. The evidence equally supports the conclusion that lacking sleep causes people to network, or that people who lack sleep and network with other people who lack sleep share other characteristics that cause them to lack sleep and/or to network. This work does identify excellent opportunities for further research. We should base our conclusions on the evidence, rather than pre-empting the outcomes of that research

item.author: Robert Houston
item.description:
The scheduled two year run of the LHC at 3.5 times the energy of the Tevatron may entail a commensurate increase in risk to the machine and environment. Smaller increments in beam energy were advised in safety measures presented in a 2009 study by German physicist Rainer Plaga, Ph.D.- at arxiv.org/abs/0808.1415v3 - which found flaws CERN's safety assumptions. It contends that CERN theorists failed to exclude a plausible possibility that the LHC may produce semi-stable microscopic black holes "emitting Hawking radiation that would be harmful to Earth and/or CERN and its surroundings" (Abs.).
An appendix to the revised paper provides a devastating rebuttal to an earlier critique by CERN theorists. A subsequent study by American physicists Crane and Westmoreland - at arxiv.org/abs/0908.1803 - also found that some microscopic black holes could release huge amounts of explosive energy, "powerful by terrestrial standards." Until the serious charges by Plaga and other concerned scientists are adequately resolved, it is irresponsible for CERN to risk environmental disaster by proceeding with particle collisions at such high beam energies.

item.author: Robert Houston
item.description:
Daniel Clery's article is commendable but needs an update. The international complaint against CERNs LHC project was filed on Nov. 20, 2009, at the Human Rights Committee of the U.N. in Geneva. The press release and 73 page document are available at the first link in the article.
As is documented in the complaint, safety assumptions for the LHC have been put in doubt by recent studies. For example, the idea that "the black holes would quickly decay" is based on the theory of Hawking radiation, which lacks empirical evidence and has been disputed by respected physicists such as Belinski (2006), Helfer (2003), and Unruh (2004). Others calculate that even with Hawking radiation some LHC-produced micro black holes could survive for extended periods, even years (Casadio and Harms, 2002). These analyses were excluded from CERN's safety review. So was the 3rd Scenario from physicist Rainer Plaga - at Arxiv.org/abs/0808.1415v3 - which concerns the limited growth of quasi-stable black holes emitting Hawking radiation that would be harmful to Earth as a whole and/or the inhabitants of CERN and its surroundings (abstract).
Linking to CERN's public safety review, Mr. Clery wrote, The main argumenthas been that collisions of similar energies happen daily in the upper atmosphere as cosmic rays slam into atoms in the air But regarding neutral microsopic black holes, the same safety review actually admits (7th Par.): Those produced by cosmic rays would pass harmlessly through the Earth into space, whereas those produced by the LHC could remain on Earth. (As in a car crash, the LHCs head-on collisions result in a slowdown.) The cosmic ray argument thus has been relocated to dense neutron stars which, as Plaga notes, are protected by powerful magnetic fields.
With its safety rationales in serious doubt this dangerous project, which threatens the very future of our world, should be halted at once.

channel.title: news.sciencemag.org/sciencenow/2010/03/did-dinosaurs-start-out-on-all-f.html comments

item.description: I should clarify one thing. It is obvious that dinosaurs evolved from a quadrupedal species, if one goess back far enough. The question though, is whatwas the immediate ancestor? To accept a quadrupedal origin, one must accept that a lineage that was evolving toward bipedality reversed itself, then reversed itself again, and then reversed itself a further time with the evolution of the quadrupedal ornithischians. This, while certainly possible, is much less likely than the idea that the silesaurs evolved toward quadrupedality while the lineage leading to dinosaurs continued its bipedal evolution.

item.author: Joe
item.description: Considering the anatomy of the most primitive dinosaurs and that of the other animals near the base, it is far more likely that this animal descended from a 2-legged ancestor and evolved toward quadrapedality while the lineage leading to the dinosaurs remained bipedal. It does not really changethe "debate" at all. It also does not push back the timing of the dinosaurs in anything other than overly simplistic cladistic interpretation. Another possibility is that the common ancestor of the silesaurs and dinosaurs continued to evolve and at some later time split off the dinosaurs. Since both this possibility and the notion that the dinsaurs evolved earlier require the assumptioon of unknown animals, it ismost prudent to accept the possibility that requires the fewest assumptions. In this case, both possibilities require the additionof unknown animals, but the hypothesis that dinosaursevolved earlier than supported by the hard evidence requires additional constraints on the nature of the missing animals and is therefore less likely to be valid. As of late, it seems more common to hype every find. While laudablefor bringing interest to the field, we should be careful about hyping finds beyond what they actually say. It is a mistake to simplify to the point of error and make interpretations before proper consideration of the possibilities.

item.author: Morten
item.description: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemolithotroph The sediment bacteria metabolize inorganic materials by peeling off electrons. These electrons must go somewhere and that is to the bacteria on the bottom of the sea (yes, Kattegat is a sea, not an ocean) where the bacteria combine elctrons, oxygen, and protons, H+, to produce water. This is an energetically downhill process and both kinds of bacteria are able to extract some of this energy to power themselves. If oxygen had spontaneously oxidized the inorganic material the energy would have been released as heat. When there is no oxygen there are no electron acceptors and the sediment bacteria can't get rid of their electrons. No need for other means of communication.

item.author: Drew Dust
item.description:
Does it need to be wires at all? Why not use the sediment itself as the conductor? No need for anything else, it's an idea that's been around since Nikola Tesla and the basis of his Wardenclyffe Tower.
Furthermore why does it need to be electricity? From what's stated here it could as easily be radiowaves or another form of electromagnetic radiation. Or if one conceives that it's electrical, then why not hydraulic? Why can't they pump chemical signals through tubes at rates faster than diffusion? (though this does seem more costly)
Unless the paper has significantly more data pointing to electricity and wires then I suspect that this review may take a great deal for granted.

item.author: Alexander from Oregon
item.description: This data seems to imply a simple conductive pathway where anaerobic bacteria shuttle reduction potential to the aerobic bacteria who then reduce oxygen. No oxygen? No current. Reduction potential builds up in the subsurface bacteria and they (as observed) stop utilizing reduced fuels such as SH2. Besides implicating just metals, Iron Pyrite (FeS2) is a p-type semiconductor and is used in all biological systems (iron-sulfur clusters in the electron transport chain), especially oceanic anaerobic sedimentary ecosystems. It would not be surprising if conductor/semiconductor dynamics based on sulfur flux has a regulatory factor in this scheme.

item.description: I am in total agreement with JV. I think that the basic finding, namely a correlation with impulsiveness, is of value. However, to then turn around and say "this why psychopaths are the way they are" without having even tested one psychopath (must less dozens or hundreds) is totally baseless and unscientific. Example: In today's (3/16/10) Washington Post is an article on a serial rapist who has been eluding police for 13 years. The man apparently studies his victims and the areas in which they live before attacking. This man most certainly is a psychopath, but he does not appear to be impulsive in the least. The Virginia Tech gunman is another example: He didn't just walk into a classroom and started shooting. Instead he first took the time to make and mail a video and then thought to secure the building by chaining the doors to hold off the police. So here is another non-impulsive psychopath.

item.author: Genevieve
item.description:
Right, this study did not test psychopaths. Joshua Buckholtz and colleagues measured a "range of psychopathic traits" in a group of volunteers. So, these tests (based on subjective answers from volunteers) gauged traits like impulsivity and anti-social behavior. I know I would test well on impulsivity!
The finding are still interesting--that the greater the score someone scores on a test for impulsive-antisocial behavior, the more pleasurable rush they feel from a stimulus. So, while it does seems to be relevant for people with actual criminal psychopathy, the study didn't go that route.
It seems that the result hold bigger implications for drug abuse and addiction in any and all people, not only psychopaths.
I think that it was based on the previous knowledge on psychopath's traits which the scientists used to do their tests.

item.author: Drew
item.description:
I wonder though, how much agricultural waste could be used for that purpose? Some "waste" is placed on the fields to reduce soil erosion.
Also, even the best biofuels options--even if we did convert cellulose to ethanol--are poor at best. Requiring enormous amounts of farmland for small gains. I've seen scientists in my area moving toward bio-chemicals. The chemical industry requires enormous amounts of petroleum for creating compounds that could produced from plants, which would reduce carbon emissions far more effectively than just burning them up as fuel. I suspect that this is where the researchers here are actually headed, just using "biofuels" as a buzzword so they can jump their publication to Science and get the next grant.

item.author: mudd1
item.description:
Actually, letting the waste decay is not a very efficient way of getting carbon into the soil. Let us hope that there will be a way to produce biofuel efficiently at a very small scale so that farms of all sizes can profit (and buy fertilizer if needed). Terra preta and hydrothermal carbonization might be interesting directions of future development to use agricultural waste to improve soils in a carbon-efficient way.
On "green" oil drilling: Even if oil production would mean nothing but a tiny hole in the ground and not a drop of it would ever be released into the environment -- this is no longer the point. It's about the carbon that is released when the oil is burned. And this will inevitably happen as long as it is taken out of the ground. For obvious reasons nobody is even thinking about CCS for cars or heatings -- personally I don't believe in it even for coal power plants.
You are right though that increased land use is not acceptable for many reasons, the huge carbon release being only one of them. But if we can use agricultural waste to produce biofuel that's already something. It won't be enough but if we can't even do this, then what else can we do right?
Hemp would provide the raw material, and lots of it. What are we waiting for?
this is exclusive

item.author: quixoticallysober

Zhang et al hypothesized that the injury cause by burns or crushes result in the release of mitochondrial DAMPs (damage-associated molecular patterns) into circulation. Their research did find that skeletal muscle damage can release mitochondrial DAMPs. The DAMPs in turn activate PMN signaling (polymormorphonuclear neutrophils) and initiate inflammation (suggestive of SIRS mechanism).
Honestly, this research is really appealing to me, does anyone know of any US institutions with a strong graduate program?

(Those attributed to the infamous "Biothrax" anthrax immunization could share this etiology, since the development of antiboidies to contaminants in that immunization could be the causative factor in all of them.) Other than in PBC, SLE, and other known syndromes with "positive antimitochondrial antibody" titers, I haven't read anything in the literature (including a quick PubMed search tonight) on autoimmune syndromes arising from autoimmunity to specific, characterized and defined mitochondrial antigens. That could simply be that no one has thought of looking. If no one has, could someone please start? (This is an area of interest to me but definitely not of my expertise.)

Maybe I grew up on the moon... I can remember when all the people I knew seemed to be mentally fit. I grew up in a small town. As I remember, we only had one town drunk. Things sure have changed.

Some say we've come a long way. Others say junk science and junk medicine. I like to think it's the government's fault, from those 10,000+ nuclear bombs they've set off. Have you ever gone door to door where old people live? When a lifelong smoker/drinker answers the door, the diminished mental capacity is apparent.
My daughter at age 2 fell into a swimming pool and nearly drowned. Then about age 13 she began to do drugs with an older boyfriend (one I should have shot). Now she is 38 and has tried suicide 7 times. Last time she almost made it to the finish line. In and out of Hospitals for short stays. Still losing to drugs, cigarettes, and alcohol.
Maybe if the psychologists and psychiatrists would spend time fighting drugs, cigarettes, and alcohol, instead of advocating them, we would have a better society. Meanwhile, the Health Insurance companies now pay their bills and the welfare departments support their patients. What a life... Does anyone have a solution ????

item.author: Carl
item.description:
Tadchen, You should know that seismic risks associated to volcanic eruptions in La Palma are rapidly attenuated in less than 1 km, and the nearest active area to Roque de los Muchachos is more than 40 km away. Infrastructures at this Observatory can be built following standard requirements, and not special measures needs to be taken on this particular issue.
Seismic risks associated to tectonic movements, like those ones in Chile, move ahead with similar Peak Ground Accelerations than origin (or even higher due to amplification effects because local conditions!) up to 300 km or more in distance. Paranal and Armazones are very close to the chilean cost, were these PGA can be up to 0,6g (mag 8 or higher)
On the other hand, seismic episodes in Chile, of high PGA and magnitude, are, unfortunately, very offen. Much, much, much offen than eruptions in La Palma, and much,much, much destructive than in La Palma. Chech information at the NEIC. Check the number of earthquakes in Chile, of relevant importance, from 1470, for instance.
So, seismic risks in La Palma are insignificant.
By the way, Massimo Tarenghi, ESO representative at Chile, says that ESO facilities are built to survive earthquakes of 9 magnitude. No civil work on Earth can be built with these requirements. Nor even nuclear plants, or the core of nuclear plants. Ask experts.

item.author: Robert Houston
item.description:
Contrary to the statement by CERNs publicist James Gillies, three of the main arguments used by collider critics in recent years and included in their March 2008 lawsuit against the LHC were conceded as essentially valid not baseless by CERNs latest safety reports (published in Aug.-Sept. 2008).
* First, CERN has acknowledged that new theories make the production of microscopic black holes by the LHC a plausible possibility, not an impossibility as CERN scientists claimed in 1999. Its chief safety consultant recently wrote, "Black hole production may be the most spectacular physics at future colliders, perhaps even beginning with the...startup of the LHC" (see arxiv.org/abs/0709.1107 ).
* Second, CERN's Aug. 2008 safety paper by Giddings and Mangano deviated from CERN's 2003 safety report by conceding doubts about "Hawking's discovery that black holes evaporate." According to these top CERN safety theorists, "it is certainly true that elements of the original derivation [by Hawking] of black hole radiance rely on assumptions that are apparently not valid" (p. 3).
* Third, CERN has conceded the validity of the critics' argument that there is a crucial difference of velocity between possible black holes created by cosmic rays versus those at the LHC. Regarding neutral "microscopic black holes," CERNs own public safety report (linked at the end of Mr. Chos article), now admits (7th Par.): Those produced by cosmic rays would pass harmlessly through the Earth into space, whereas those produced by the LHC could remain on Earth.
Consequently, CERNs theorists have relocated the cosmic ray argument to dense neutron stars and white dwarf stars, but critics have pointed out various holes in such examples. For instance, such dense stars are protected by powerful magnetic fields, and neutron stars are believed to consist partly of strange matter, a feared outcome for Earth of possible strangelet production by the LHC. More objections are specified in the 73-page international complaint to the U.N, which presents a powerful and well-documented indictment of the inadequacies of CERNs safety reviews.

item.author: Joe D.
item.description: I see a couple of problems here. First, it begins with the presumption that fairness is the normal behavior. I beg to differ. It seems to me this is a rose-colored view of the world with little evidence to support it. We live in a society in which lying is not only considered acceptable, but is implicitly, if not explicitly, encouraged. This is antithetical to fairness. Second, artificial games like this really don't tell us much. The problems interpreting them when used in other cultures is well known. What seems to be less commonly noted is that college students who know they are playing a game and know other people are watching act differently when they think they are not being judged. Actions by people who think no one will know what they did are generally very different than when they think people will know. As evidence, simply look at any comment section on a web page. The preponderance of comments are things most people would say in polite society.

channel.title: news.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2010/03/elsevier-to-editor-change-contro.html comments

item.author: Marco Ruggiero
item.description:
According to Elsevier, our article contains highly controversial opinions about the causes of AIDS, opinions that could potentially be damaging to global public health. However, it is a fact that the article did not contain any opinion of ours about the causes of AIDS; it merely interpreted policies, directive and web pages of the Italian Ministry of Health. In addition, it appears that the Ministry and the Public Health Service considered our withdrawn article indeed helpful for improving (Italian) public health and actually modified policies and web pages according to the comments put forward in our paper in July 2009. For example, in our article we lamented the fact that a national HIV surveillance program did not exist, as then stated in the Ministrys web pages. Following the short-lived publication of our article, the Ministry changed the concerned web pages; now it still admits that only 6 out of 20 regions of Italy have implemented a surveillance system. But, unlike in the previous web page, it also clarifies that a Ministrys decree was emanated in 2008 demonstrating that the necessity of a national surveillance system was acknowledged even though the system is not yet operating on a national scale. Thus it is a fact that our criticisms were acknowledged by the Ministry begun to provide much needed clarification (for the sake of public health).
Furthermore, as repeatedly stated in the article, the starting point of the paper was the thesis of a student, Matteo P. Galletti (please see in the Introduction To this end, a young student (MPG) preparing his bachelors thesis ). After publication of the article and, more important, after its withdrawal, the thesis of Matteo P. Galletti received official recognition by the Italian Public Health Service and the thesis is now available at the Center for Study and Research on Drug Abuse and AIDS (www.cesda.net), a Department of the Public Health Service (see http://www.cesda.net/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article&sid=1340 ; the reader will notice that the thesis of Dr. Galletti was posted on September 14, 2009). Thus it is a fact that the Public Health Service considered important and helpful for public health to publish and share the information that led to the censored Medical Hypotheses article.
As a British Nobel Laureate wrote me on August 22nd, 2009 on this subject Well, let me just comment that it seems either they couldnt follow the article or it was to save embarrassment in high places.

item.author: Peter Duesberg
item.description:
The current revisions of the standards and scope of Medical Hypotheses by Elsevier appear to be an ex post facto justification for a raid on two MeHy-papers that were published online in June 2009 - but threatened the global HIV-AIDS dogma. The submission and revisions of our paper were 100% consistent with the Medical Hypotheses standards of June 2009 and were going on for several weeks including the week when it was censored.
It is highly questionable that two papers were censored simultaneously because of concern for "global publlc health", as Elsevier argues. This is particularly unlikely since there is no known precedent for censoring published papers in recent history. Thus the raid on our papers must have been for their specific contents.
The specific content of our paper was that there is no evidence for a viral AIDS epidemic in Africa. The virus-AIDS hypothesis predicted since 1984 an exponential spread or "explosion" of a sexually transmitted AIDS epidemic, which did not happen in the US, nor in Europe in 26 years. It was then supposed to happen at least in Africa. Instead our, now censored paper showed primary evidence that the African population was exploding rather than being decimated by HIV in the last 25 years.
It seems that a Blitz on our papers was indeed the only way to save the virus-AIDS hypothesis for the time being.
Peter Duesberg

item.author: Guest
item.description: What are hypotheses without support from the facts? Should these things find their place in scientific journals? Of course I must be free to say that monkeys can fly, but should a scientific journal present this hypothesis? Among very many hypotheses one might be true, and in 100 hundred years someone might say that this idea appeared for the first time in a bizarre scientific journal back in 2010. But at the cost of publishing other dozens of rubbish papers, is this acceptable and effective? I don't think this can ever be the goal of a scientific journal, and if Elsevier wants to maintain a reputation for its journals, it's understandable that MH is asked to change. People can discuss whatever they want and they should be allowed to do so, but in other places.

channel.item:
jsid-1268190229-497 <jskit:attribute key="like" value="[{
profile: 'WrSNnt.7HwpsecDBt1bu8w',
name: ''
}
]"> Wed, 10 Mar 2010 03:03:49 +0000
Martin Enserink describes an impressive case of censorship and cleansing of scientific minorities by Elsevier on behalf of prominent HIV researchers. Elsevier took these extreme actions because of an article of ours HIV-AIDS hypothesis out of touch with South African AIDS A new perspective (by H. Bauer, C. Fiala, J. Nicholson, D. Rasnick and myself) published online in Medical Hypotheses in June 2009.
Our article responded to Harvard researchers Max Essex, Pride Chigwedere et al., who had blamed former President Mbeki, others, and us in the Journal of AIDS for the HIV-deaths of hundreds of thousands of South Africans between 2000 and 2005. According to Essex, et al. we were responsible for these deaths just by calling the HIV-AIDS hypothesis into question. The Harvard researchers had estimated these high numbers of deaths based on anonymous statistics from the World Health Organization in Geneva. But the statistics of the WHO have been criticized in 2007 for unfounded extrapolations by its former director James Chin from the University of California at Berkeley in his book, The AIDS pandemic: The collision of epidemiology with political correctness.
In response to these charges we investigated the evidence for verifiable AIDS statistics from South Africa, the USA, and the World Bank and have found that, contrary to the hundreds of thousands of lost lives claimed by Essex et al., the South African population had grown by 3 million, from 44.5 to 47.5 million, between 2000-2005 even though between 25 and 30% of the population were reported to be HIV-positive. Indeed the World Bank reported that since the beginning of the AIDS epidemic in the 1980s the Sub-Saharan African population had grown from 400 to 800 million!
The HIV researchers, who called on Elsevier to censor our paper to protect their HIV-peers from our rebuttal, included Francoise Barre-Sinoussi, co-HIV-Nobelist with Luc Montagnier, prominent HIV-researcher Moore and unnamed others.
In view of this it comes as a surprise that so much HIV prominence, status and nobility would depend on such medieval measures as censorship and the termination of the editor of a long-established British journal to refute our theory that AIDS is a chemical rather than a viral epidemic. Why would these HIV luminaries not use the time-tested method of refuting our theory with facts and logic in print, rather than by censorship based on obscure reasons?
Ever the optimist, I expected Science to take a stand against science-by-censorship and for classical open debate, much as it did in 1988. At that time Science editor Dan Koshland published a policy forum about the cause of AIDS, in which Blattner, Gallo and Temin argued for the virus hypothesis and I argued for chemical AIDS.
Is even Science now worried about the consequences of questioning viral AIDS from the global HIV-AIDS establishment?
Peter Duesberg

item.description:
The problem (and it is a gigantic problem) is that the military does not understand the local population. Atran is exactly right, the troops need to understand the local population before they go in to do what ever it is then need to do.
What is gigantically more important (mega-mega-mega-gigantically more important) is that the military leaders need to understand the local population before those military leaders tell those troops in theater what their mission is.
This is the problem that the US military is having in Iraq and Afghanistan. The Bush administration didn't know, and didn't care about the difference between Shiites and Sunni Muslims. They started out the Iraq invasion with shock and awe, expecting Iraqis to simply surrender, and then great the troops as liberators.
Good mission goals and winning the hearts and minds of the local population isn't something that can be sprinkled on at the end by throwing some social academics in with the active troops. It won't work. It is nonsense and wishful thinking to think that it would work.
Military leaders don't need to know secret information, they need to know and understand the day-to-day lives of the local population, so they can figure out what to do to win their hearts and minds. Trying to pursue bad policies based on ignorance, wishful thinking and projection until those policies fail will make implementing policies that actually have a chance of eventually working that much more difficult and costly. If you want to find the bottle neck, look at the top of the bottle.

item.author: tadchem
item.description: It is important here to stay focussed upon the ultimate objective - the value of human life. In theory governments are created to protect lives, and the military is a tool (albeit the one of last resort) of government to protect those lives. The ethical dilemma for the humanist (and the social scientist) is that there are some people and governments that choose to act to harm people, or to allow people to suffer. If there is a way to protect those who would be harmed from those who would cause harm, without harming anyone, it is often not easy to see. In particular the 'warrior' is a person who will not deviate from his task, even when it requires him to harm others, as long as he has the means to act. Whether the warrior is a suicide bomber or a US Marine, he cannot be stopped without harming him. If the ethic is to prevent harm, then the ethic itself renders the humanist incapable of acting.

item.author: scott atran
item.description: (My posted response just now was jumbled so here it is as it shoud be.) As I stated in my testimony at the Senate, it is science-based FIELD research that is most important (there's lots of terrorism research out there, but pretty useless for countering the national security threat where it ultimately counts - in the next and future generations of mostly young people). Karaleah Riechart correctly argues that it will be a hard sell to get closer cooperation between the military and anthropolgy -- as well as other social sciences--that is both transparent and unharmful . But for our national health, including keeping our service men and women out of harm's way but also preventing others from being harmed by ill informed actions, it is a process that really should start. There will be tensions and deep disagreements, but if social science does not engage power, then social science helps itself and all others to become unwitting slaves of power. Scott Atran

item.author: Perry Clark
item.description: The primary article raises rather more questions than it solves, and is all the more intriguing for it. But one should note that the research was done solely with one species of pipefish; it's not clear one can or should conclude that all male syngnathids respond in the same way to the variances in their mates. Also, it's not clear that the action is behavioral; there could well be some real difference in the eggs of larger, "more attractive" females that produces a physiologic response here interpreted as "choice". Other explanations can easily be postulated as well. Many avenues for research branching from this.

item.author: Synbio
item.description: It would be neat to use this to study the social interactions of animals that aren't easily tracked. Whales probably have a similar mini-ecosystem. Each animal could be tagged with a bacteria containing a unique DNA sequence. A system could be engineered to use CRISPR's to record recent physical contact with any other animals. You could then scrap some bacteria off the animal, sequence the bacteria, and identify all the other animals it contacted recently. I could imagine a way to make the engineered bacteria determine if it is the only engineered bacteria on the animal and generate a new tag. This way you could tag all animals uniquely only needing to come in contact with a few of them.

item.author: B
item.description:
They will most likely quantify and give probabilities.Obviously there is always the chance of contamination (just as can occur with DNA samples from a CSI). Yet, I believe there may be some smoking gun examples under various situations. Just as Anthrax has been profiled and regional variations can be determined based on genetic makeup. Therefore, I think other microbial profiling can be used to determine a higher certainty.
Consider the bioaccumulation of various minerals and the ability to trace antlers to the region where they feed.

item.author: jj2204
item.description: @rintintin you're confusing psychologists with psychiatrists. Although psychologists can study the mental aspects of schizophrenia, major depression, Alzheimer's and autism, every single one of those disorders has a biological cause. Thinking that a psychologist can find a "cure" (i.e. a medical/biological treatment) for them is a little ridiculous.
